nodes.bodyText: Instead of calling the raw method, do we have a method in customizedStateConfig to get the types?
getEnabledCustomizedStateTypes()?
Same, the name should reflect what we set. Moreover, do we need this set to be public?
It's likely to be only used in test for now. So I keep it as public.
The map is initialized as en empty map. Do we need to check for NPE here?
Haven't we refreshed this in the BaseControllerDataProvider, can we just use that result here?

If you passed "this", I guess you don't need to pass "_aggregationEnabledTypes" in addition. You can always call BaseControllerDataProvider.getCustomizedStateConfig() in the CustomizedStateCache. And that method is safer and cleaner.

My major concern is that it relies on the reference of the input set (aggregationEnabledTypes) to accept any types update. Ideally, it should be read explicitly in the CustomizedStateCache logic. So it exactly knows that this set might have been changed. For now, every read of this set in the CustomizedStateCache can return different content. This may introduce bugs.

I agree. I suggest we defer the decision in the next PR together with the controller. The main reason is that then I can show easily which test is broken with the change in controller logic and cache change. We can decide whether changing the test logic makes more sense or the cache logic.
I think if we add it here, it will be done by the Task pipeline as well. Is it necessary?

Currently I do not see the usage of customized state in task pipeline. I kept it here mainly for two reasons, one is that it's similar to current state cache, and easier to identify and debug if we put them together, also it keeps some assumption of our tests. The other reason is that we may have extended use case in the future, our TF users may also have some customized state they need.
This will increase the read throughput and pipeline latency, which is one of the major concerns. Before we have a real use case, I prefer to keep it in the resource data provider only.

This logic confused me. Are we setting curCustomizedViews or customizedViewCache? Or both?
Could you please split these 2 parts?

The logic here is that if customizedViewCache is not null, we will get the mapping (resource -> customizedView) from the cache, and use that in the later computation stage. However, if the customizedViewCache is null, meaning the stateType does not exist in the customizedViewCache list, we will initialize a new customizedViewCache for it.
I think this has been done in the external view stage. There is no need to do it twice.
Shall we just pass the in-memory content to the cache instead of requiring it to read from ZK again?
I tried to use in-memory content, and that does require a couple of set functions in CustomizedViewCache. I feel it's not clean. Please let me know if you think it's worth.
Worth it. Because if you have 1K resources, you might refresh 1K times, right?

But, actually, I have another question even before that. Why do you need to refresh this cache? It is not used in the following logic. And as for the next pipeline, it will refresh the cache from ZK anyway.
Finally, in your previous logic, CustomizedViewCache could be a newly created instance (created by "new CustomizedViewCache(event.getClusterName(), stateType);" And you are not put it back to the Resource Cache), right? So refresh it does not help anyone in my understanding. Please correct me if I missed anything.

I remove all the cache refresh/remove logic in this stage. But let me double check. I saw external view computation stage does have cache refresh and remove, and I'll make sure the cache is not used anywhere.

nit, safer to add a protected readonly method for getting the list instead of returning the list. Otherwise, the children may modify this list.

Can we explicitly call this outside the refreshCustomizedStateConfig and just before _customizedStateCache.refresh()? Since _customizedStateCache.setAggregationEnabledTypes and refresh must be ordered, putting them together is easier for us to understand and maintain.
More accurate to convert the 2 lists to sets for assertion? If the ordering is different, this assert would fail.
I thought the children were retrieved in a certain order, but by looking at the code, seems actually it's random based on the order whichever child is gotten back first. Is it right?

Ordering is not guaranteed. In ZK's Znode implementation, it is using a set to store children. And it is converted to a list when returning to the client. So the ordering could be random.
If you are just checking if they have the same element without ordering, I would suggest using Sets so ordering is ignored. Only if you also want to check the ordering, a list is more appropriate.
And also here. Collection vs List. Would be better to make them 2 sets.
